PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Second Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [24th February, 1986],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the Second Session of this Parliament.".' - [Dr Aline K. Wong]

Column: 96



    Question again proposed.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee (Boon Lay): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Economic Committee's Report referred to in the Presidential Address has recommended short and long term measures to stimulate growth. It has recommended immediate cost reduction to help our companies to regain competitiveness and to attract investment. In addition to a 15% cut in the employers' rate of CPF contributions, the Committee proposed a wage restraint in the next two years.

    Sir, it would appear rather easy to achieve cost reduction by simply applying

Column: 97

a policy and administrative decision to cut the CPF rate of contribution. To the workers it means a pay cut, a cut in their savings. But the workers would, I believe, accept the cut if they understand that such a move is indeed necessary to save jobs and to create jobs. But one must realize that although a cut in the CPF rate of contribution will help our companies, in particular the efficiently managed companies, to strengthen their competitiveness, it will at the same time help the inefficient companies to remain viable. Already we have heard complaints by some employers crying that a 15% cut is not enough. There are companies who because of poor management will never be able to compete, no matter how low the wage cost is. And there are those who like to operate in Singapore but are only prepared to pay Sri-Lankan wages. Should we make up for the lack of business acumen and efficiency on the part of these employers by further reducing the wage cost and CPF? My answer is no. And I think it is wrong to create in the minds of the employers that if their companies could not perform up to expectation, the Government will help them further by cutting deeper into the CPF or the wages.

    Sir, while I agree with the suggestion of the Economic Committee to exercise severe wage restraint in the next two years, I do not think that freezing the workers' wages across the board for all companies, regardless of their financial and competitive positions, is a desirable or practical proposition.

    The wage levels of different companies, even those in the same business, are different. The average wage cost of a newly established company can be significantly lower than that of a long-established company. The significance of wage cost as a percentage of the total operating cost as well as the performance and profitability of companies differ too. Whilst certain companies may require a wage cut to remain viable, there will be some who can afford to make incremental adjustments, small though it may be. As an illustration, if the average wage of the production workers of a company is, say, $400 as against the industry average of, say $600, there is no reason why the company should be prevented from offer-

Column: 98

ing some increments or incentive payments to their employees if the company can afford to do so, and indeed intend to do so. On the other hand, if the average wage of the workers of a company is significantly higher than the industry average and the company is facing financial difficulties, then a wage freeze may not even be enough. So whilst it is wise and necessary to implement a national policy of wage restraint for the next one or two years, we should not have an across-the-board policy to freeze wages. We should not replace one form of wage rigidity by another form of rigidity. We must allow for flexibility, which is the principle advocated so strongly and forcefully by the Economic Committee.

    Sir, one of the main objectives of the present exercise to reduce costs is really to preserve jobs and to create jobs. This is meaningful only if the companies re-invest their profits to expand their operations and create employment. It would be morally wrong for companies to distribute increased profits and savings resulted from wage cost reduction by way of higher dividends and bonuses to shareholders and managers. We cannot possibly expect the workers to accept wage freeze if at the same time the managers are getting increased bonuses. This may sound unlikely to happen at this time but the sad thing is that it does happen.

    There was this company which has made more profits in 1985 than in 1984. After having paid the managerial staff increased bonuses (in fact, three months' bonuses), the company now comes to the union to ask for wage freeze for the bargainable employees. Is this fair? Should we allow this?

    What I am trying to say, Sir, is that our workers will be prepared to accept wage freeze or, if necessary, wage cut and the unions will be able to help to explain and convince the workers to exercise restraint provided the cost cutting measures are applied fairly and equitably and that the workers do not perceive their losses as somebody else's gains. There is a Chinese saying (Guo bu huan qiong zhi huan bu jun (    ). Translated into English, it means: A nation's concern or worry is not poverty. Its main worry is

Column: 99

inequity. There is much wisdom in this saying. And all those in charge of companies, corporations or the Government should take note of this.

    With the wage restraint and cut in CPF, will our workers suffer a serious drop in the standard of living? One indication to watch is the cost of living and inflation. Just as wages are difficult to come down, so are the prices of goods and services.

    In the past, whenever the NWC made its recommendations, the prices of hawker food would go up. So would the costs of other goods and services. Even the bus fare and other Government charges went up, usually justified on the ground of increased wage cost. With the proposed wage restraint and the CPF cut of 15%, will the cost of hawker food go down by 15%? Will the bus fare go down by 15%? Will HDB rental and conservancy charges go down too?I would think that all organizations, Government or private, who provide services to the public and who have in the past raised their charges by citing reason of higher wage cost, have the moral obligation to lower their fees after the implementation of cost cutting measures announced by the Government.

    I do not intend to dwell further on this matter. But suffice it to say that the Government should monitor the cost of living closely. If the wages are held constant but the inflation goes up to the extent of hurting our people badly, especially the low income group, then temporary measures like reducing the employee's contributions to CPF should be considered. This is to enable the workers to have a higher take home pay to tide over the difficult times. It is well for the Government to be paternalistic and insist that every Singaproean must own a home. But let us set our priorities right. To the low income group, their immediate concern is to make ends meet. Owning a home is of secondary importance. I think the Government should recognize this.

    Sir, the suggestion to cut personal income tax, as proposed by the Economic Committee, appears to be an attractive proposition. But at the same time, the

Column: 100

Committee has suggested that the Government should shift from direct to indirect taxes as its main source of revenue. If the idea is that the loss in the Government revenue resulting from a cut in income tax should be made up by the imposition of indirect tax, such as consumption tax or sales tax, then I would urge the Government to consider very carefully the impact of such a consumption tax on the low income group. In contrast with income tax, is progressive and places heavier tax on higher income, the general application of sales or consumption tax is regressive and places relatively heavier burden on the lower income group who spend most, if not all, of their income on food, clothing and other basic necessities. I would not support any move to impose the sales or consumption tax now or in the future, unless a tax is imposed selectively, only on the non-essential items and services. By all means, impose taxes on those who patronize restaurants and nightclubs. But do not ask our poor wage earners to pay tax at hawker centres, markets or provision shops.

    Sir, in the Report, the Economic Committee has focussed its attention on ways and means of helping our businessmen and employers. This is rightly so as the recovery of our economy hinges on the viability and success of our business enterprises. But at the same time, we must be sympathetic to the plight of the workers who lost their jobs in the current recession. In this connection, I would urge the Government to pay special attention to the retrenched workers, particularly the middle-aged and older workers. The problem which the older retrenched workers are facing is that the employers are reluctant to employ them. There are prejudices against the older workers. In many instances, the employers are not willing to employ older workers even if they are prepared to accept a lower salary. Furthermore, most of the jobs that are available and the new jobs that are created do not suit the older workers. For instance, those who are retrenched by the shipyards could not possibly find jobs in the new electronic or computer firms. This problem of structural unemployment will become more serious in the years to come.

Column: 101



    There is an urgency for us to tackle this problem. The Economic Committee has suggested several measures to encourage the employment of older workers. I would, in principle, support the measures recommended, including the proposal to reduce the CPF contribution rate for older workers. I would go further to suggest that the Government should take a lead and set an example in offering employment to the older workers. Certain jobs should be reserved exclusively for the older workers. As an illustration, let us look at the job of URA and HDB car park attendants. I think it is a mere waste of valuable manpower resources for the young men and girls in their 20's and 30's to do such unproductive work; walking and strolling around the car park. They are able-bodied and should be working in the productive sector of our economy. The job of car park attendants and wardens should rightly be reserved for people who are, say, over 50 years of age. When the URA and the HDB recruit car park attendants, they should not look for young and pretty girls. They should employ older men and women.

    What I have just quoted is one example. I am sure there are other jobs which can likewise be done by the older workers. Perhaps the Government should form a task force to identify such jobs. Stop recruiting young and able-bodied persons for the relatively simple and unproductive jobs. Give the older workers a chance.

    Sir, in conclusion, I would like to express my support of the broad strategies and policies recommended by the Economic Committee. The Committee's Report is no doubt a very comprehensive one. There may be differences in views in some specific proposals among different interested parties. But that should not divert our attention from the basic issue and the pressing need to enhance our competitiveness, attract investment, stimulate growth and create jobs.

    Let us also not forget that how soon we can get out of the current recession depends not only on our own effort but also on the development in the world and in the region. Our neighbouring countries are also facing difficulties. They have revised their growth targets more than

Column: 102

once and the future is still not that certain. If we do not make painful adjustments now, we may lose out both in the short term and in the long run.

    For Singaporeans, this is a time when our ability and determination to work as a team to withstand and overcome adversities is put to the test. Can all Singaporeans, whether they are employers or workers, work cohesively with the new generation of political leaders to overcome the current difficulties, or will we just quarrel among ourselves and sink in the process? This is the question. And I would like to believe that the answer to this question would be a positive one.

    Sir, I support the motion standing in the name of the Member for Changkat.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Potong Pasir made some allegations against Government yesterday which have been very ably rebutted by my colleagues on the other side.

    He also raised some interesting points, Mr Speaker, and I propose to see if I can develop these points.

    Sir, I took the Member's ideas back home. I thought over them. I mulled over them. I could not sleep. And I must admit that I came to, not one, but a few cul-de-sacs, to use the Member's term. I refer to his rule of thumb, Mr Speaker, wherein he said that the cost of a dwelling house should only be about three times the gross income of a worker for three years. That is a rule of thumb, I presume. But I also presume that rules of thumb work.

    Let us take his example, for instance. He said:

    '$1,000 a month for three years. It is $36,000. Therefore, a flat should not cost the person $36,000. It should be $36,000 or less.' As long as the Member for Potong Pasir does not elaborate on that point, then I submit, Mr Speaker, that his rule of thumb is not reliable. It does not work. I tried to make it work but it could not work. Therefore, what he says is unreliable. Does he propose, for instance, to apply this $36,000

Column: 103

to take his example to a 2-room flat, a 3-room flat, a 4-room flat, a 5-room executive flat or an HUDC flat? I am not sure. He did not say so. But I make a point and the point is you cannot decide on how much to sell a flat basing on a person's salary. It should be properly costed out, on materials, on manpower and so on.

    I submit also, Mr Speaker, Sir, that his allegation on the HDB prices is also not true. Members will recall that he did not agree with the Member for Changkat. I think he said something like that. He did not agree with the Member for Changkat that the prices of HDB flats are cheap. And then he said, "You go and tell your constituents and you will lose your election."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, his logic for that, if I can recall, is that he said, "You cannot compare private sector prices with public sector prices." I presume he still maintains that. If he maintains that, then, Mr Speaker, can you see a little loophole in his argument later on and I propose to show it. Because he said in his speech somewhere, if I can recall, when he proposed that rule of thumb, he said something like, "You should know that in Western countries the cost of a private dwelling house should not be more than three times the gross income of a worker for three years." He is proposing that the Government use this rule of thumb which is meant to be for a private dwelling in Western countries to public sector housing in Singapore. I cannot see the rationale. And therefore I propose, Mr Speaker, that all that he has said yesterday, all his allegations against the Government are totally untrue.
11.23 am

     Dr Dixie Tan (Ulu Pandan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion of thanks moved by the Member for Changkat for the President's Address.

    I am in broad agreement with the recommendations in the speech. But today I wish to focus on the role of the medical services in the context of economic recovery and economic growth in the future. I must declare that I have a vested interest in this area but the same interest allows me also a few special insights, I hope.

Column: 104



    Let us review first the status of medical care in Singapore. We have in Singapore doctors to the population ratio of about 1:1000. This compares very favourably with the 1:600 population in most developed countries. Among our doctors, one in three hold a specialist degree. Again, a very high and very respectable figure for specialization. Our medical school which is well recognized throughout the Commonwealth produces 200 graduates a year.

    We have a long tradition of training for nurses. We have had for the last two decades or more a good proportion of nurses who hold not only basic nursing qualifications but post-basic nursing expertise and certificates in many branches, such as intensive care nursing, paediatric nursing, psychiatric nursing and so on.

    We have hospitals which provide good care for patients, both in the public and the private sectors. With these good basic facilities, there is very high and good potential for growth so that over and above the needs of our own population, we can offer these services to non-Singaporeans.

    So let us think what will sell because that is what we wish to do, to sell our medical services. Services which are not available in other people's hometown or country will be the ones that people will come over here to look for. And these, by and large, boil down to specialist services, particularly in surgery but also in many of the sub specialities. So I think we need to focus on specialities, firstly.

    Secondly, our profession in the medical services must have a consistently high standard. It does not do to have eight good specialists and two very bad ones. What we need to achieve is an image that Singapore medical care equals good high quality medical care, in the same way that when we think of a Swiss watch, we think of a good watch. So I think standards are very important, particularly in the private sector.

    In the Government sector, there are systems for appraisal. There are certain standards and certain official recognition

Column: 105

of expertise. But in the private sector where many of the doctors are self employed, there is no such uniform system. I will come back to this a little later on.

    Thirdly, and most importantly, charges must be affordable. We live in a region where per capita income is not very high. To be sure, this is a region of growth and of great potential. But right now, affordability is a very very important consideration when we are wanting to sell medical services to the surrounding region. I might add that charges do not include only medical charges, such as professional charges, hospital charges, laboratory and X-ray charges. They also include factors like hotel charges, restaurant charges, because relatives of patients have to stay in hotels, they have to eat in restaurants and they have to travel around by taxi. However, for today, I will not dwell on these non-medical aspects but confine my remarks to medical aspects.

    So I thought over the various possibilities or the method for achieving this goal so that the medical service can become an important sector of our economy in the future. The public sector, and this includes Government as well as the National University of Singapore, has the primary function of serving our own population. We have a good record of high standard care for all of our population in the way of direct service care, in the way of training of doctors, nurses and other professionals and very important in playing a leading role in the profession so that we can keep up with all the continuing advances in medicine. I believe that with modest reinforcements in the way of support services and style and in the way of new radical thinking, the public service sector in medicine can be more efficient and can generate surplus in their services so that over and above serving our own population, there will be potential capability for serving non-Singaporeans as well.

    What are the proposals then that I would wish for the public sector? I think one of the most important areas is a change in management style. Our management style dates back to colonial days where a doctor came out from England usually, and was the Head of Department in control of a whole section, and therefore "everything"

Column: 106

including management. However, I find it hard to believe that somebody who may have spent four years studying management and another four or five years working in management would not be better at managing than someone else who has studied five years in Medicine as an undergraduate and another four years in Medicine as a post-graduate and perhaps spent nine months studying hospital administration. Also, it is a terrible waste of medical study to put a medical specialist into a management position.

    Secondly, we need to promote the image of our many very excellent departments in the medical service. We have departments with very excellent equipment and very high level personnel who can work these equipment and provide services. I think it is high time that our medical services dropped their Cinderella image.

    Thirdly, many of our professionals are not working optimally. By this I mean that they are not getting enough secretarial help, nursing help and organizational help. I think it is a terrible waste to have a consultant write out his own report in long hand, putting a carbon paper underneath his report sheet in order that the carbon copy can be sent back to a referring doctor who has trouble reading the carbon copy. I think this is a waste of money and very inefficient.

    Finally, once we have reorganized and become more efficient, this surplus potential for service can easily be put to work in private wings which can be attached to our major government hospitals.

    These suggestions, if properly implemented, will increased efficiency in service to the benefit of our own citizens as well as to the benefit of other citizens who come from abroad. In case some people in the private sector say that government should not compete with the private sector, it is my belief that we do need a strong government sector in medicine because it is the government and university professionals who have responsibility for producing our future doctors, who have the responsibility for holding the standards and for leading the advancing edge in medicine. If the public sector were to

Column: 107

deteriorate in standard and numbers because they are non-competitive and because they are inefficient, then I think our country will be the worse for it in later years.

    Coming to the private sector, I think there is no need for the private sector to be afraid of competition from the government sector. The private sector has nothing to do but to provide a service. They have no encumbrances like bureaucracy, waiting for budgets, and things like that. All they have to do is to give good service. There is no good reason why they cannot compete effectively with the government sector even if the government sector were to offer services to private patients. As it is, the service in the private sector is already being extended to sizeable numbers of non-Singaporeans. However, all of us in the profession know that the clientele has declined in the last year or two, along with the decline in the economies of our neighbouring countries as well as along with the escalating charges that the patients have to pay. So, to the private sector, I would like to commend a reading of the Economic Report. The private sector must and should act to regain their competitive edge and I would like to propose a few methods for doing so.

    The private sector should reorganize itself into medical centres. What I mean by a medical centre is a cohesive group of a hospital or clinic together with a group of committed doctors so that the hospital and the doctors work as one unit. In this way there can be great savings in personnel, savings in floor areas and in equipment. A simple calculation will tell you that three surgeons sitting in three different offices would do better if they shared one office. This could be done if they were all part of the one organization. Then there is duplication of equipment, which is a very expensive item and which needs to be replaced frequently if we are to keep up with advances in medicine. Re-duplication can be much reduced by a combination of professionals as well as laboratories and other services. In this way, with the pooling, the savings that accrue can partly be ploughed back into the service centre,

Column: 108

into the medical centre, so that the centre can continually upgrade and be competitive.

    Secondly, I hark back to my previous remarks on high professional standards. I believe that we need to have some kind of definite recognition as to who is a specialist in Singapore. This is very important. When people come from elsewhere they have no way of distinguishing one person from another, both of whom may have equally long strings of incomprehensible letters after their name. At this moment, our basic qualification for doctors to practise is their bachelor's degree which they get after their undergraduate studies. We do not have a roll of specialists which says that so and so is now qualified in paper degree as well as in experience to be a reliable specialist in a particular field. I believe that this is the time for Government or else for Government to appoint a reliable body to create such a roll of specialists, so that people coming from broad, and indeed even our own patients, will be able to find their way to reliable specialists who can then give them a consistently high level of care.

    Some people become specialists because they have certain qualifications and certain experience. And having become a specialist or indeed even a family physician, there is no guarantee that they will keep up their standards. Medicine advances every year and there is a great need for continuing medical education. I was amused yesterday to hear about continuing education for people who had not achieved their PSLE. It is equally important for doctors who have achieved their MBBS and other specialist qualifications to also have continuing education.

    If we had a roll of specialists, we could actually incorporate these requirements for continuing education into a re-registration exercise so that registration is not a life-time thing but is perhaps a five-year thing.

     Dr Aline K. Wong (Changkat): Every five years.

     Dr Dixie Tan: One needs to show proof that one is still qualified to be a specialist. Strangely enough, the best models for specialist care with which satisfy all these

Column: 109

requirements: efficiency, good caring for patients and good salaries for the people who work there, are to be found in the developed countries where salaries are high, working hours are relatively short, and far away from many of the developing countries whose people go all the way, for instance, to certain clinics in the United States. How do they do it? I think if they can do it, we can also do it. But when I look at the models, and I will mention only the Mayo Clinic which, in my opinion, is a very good model to follow; first and last, they give high quality care to patients. Secondly, their charges are still affordable despite high salaries, short working hours and distance from many of their patients. First and foremost, they gave very consistently high quality care. Having done that for many years, they developed a surplus fund from which they were able to go into research and so on. The Mayo Clinic is in the forefront of research. But this did not come by chance or by happen-stance. They came because of the hard work put in by their doctors and by their administrators. The doctors do not bother about the charges, about the facilities, about anything except patient care. The administrators take care that their professionals work at optimal level and that all the supporting services that are required by these professionals are catered for. Now, in recent years, the Mayo Clinic has become so good in their research that they have gone into teaching of undergraduates and are recognized by many of the medical schools.

    In Singapore we have seen the emergence of a private hospital set up by the Government. This is the National University Hospital. I think the Hospital is quite ambitious and the motives are good. However, looking at it, I think this Hospital has its priorities wrong. A hospital which is charged with the duty of producing our generations of doctors should first and foremost concentrate on the teaching of undergraduates. Secondly, it should concentrate on research. Only finally should it concentrate on giving the kind of service that we expect to give for non-Singaporeans and for private patients. Therefore, where the National University Hospital is concerned, it is not a good model for us. If this model for private

Column: 110

medical services should fail, let us not be discouraged. I would call on the private sector of medical specialists to reorganize themselves into efficient units to police themselves so that only the best people with good qualifications and experience will participate in these centres in order that we can achieve our objectives of consistently high medical care at affordable prices. I think in this way the medical services of Singapore can play a very significant part in the economy of our country.

    Mr Speaker, I have high hopes for medical service in this country. I have high hopes that we will give our own people very good medical care as has been done in the past. And over and above this, I have high hopes that we can and we will give very high quality medical care to people in the surrounding countries both for their benefit as well as for our benefit.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have an amendment to the Motion. Sir, may I move that first and then speak on the motion and the amendment generally?

     Mr Speaker: Carry on.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,
